item.title: POSTDOC POSITION - Large machine learning models for computational epidemiology
item.description:
We are hiring a postdoctoral researcher to work full-time on the DiscoReel project. The postdoc will work on developing machine and deep learning methods for epidemic modeling, integrating them with mechanistic models and focusing on foundation models. The candidate should have a background in computer science, physics or applied math and previous experience in designing and traning large machine learning models. No prior experience in epidemiology is needed, but interest in applying computational modeling to improve public health is required.

The position is likely to start in early 2026 and last 1 year, renewable. The postdoc will be employed by Inserm (French National Institute of Health and Medical Research) and will also be affiliated to the Faculty of Health of Sorbonne University. Salary will be according to Inserm’s national salary grids. The postdoc will work at the Sorbonne Outbreaks Modeling Center (SUMOC) and Pierre Louis Institute of Epidemiology and Public Health (IPLESP), interacting with senior and junior modelers and epidemiologists.

If you fit the profile and are interested in having more information please contact Eugenio Valdano. To apply for the position please use this link. The position will be filled as soon a suitable candidate is found.

item.title: Internship - Causal analysis of PrEP and sexual behavior in MSM
item.description:
We are opening an internship position at Inserm (Paris) to work on the causal analysis of PrEP uptake and sexual behavior change among MSM, as part of the PP-IMPACT project funded by ANRS-MIE. The intern will work under the supervision of Eugenio Valdano and Charles Assaad, expert in causal inference. The analysis will use observational cohort data from Portugal and France to identify bidirectional causal links between behavior and PrEP adoption.

If you would like to have more information please contact either E. Valdano or C. Assaad.

To apply for the internship please use this link. The position will be filled as soon a suitable candidate is found.

item.title: Internship - Creation of a user interface for mobility-based epidemic risk monitoring in resource-constrained settings
item.description:
Patterns of human mobility shape spatial contact networks that determine how respiratory pathogens spread and how well surveillance systems detect epidemic activity. Mathematical models can combine large-scale mobility data with epidemiological surveillance to estimate and forecast epidemic risk (see this for example).

In many resource-limited settings, there is limited capacity to handle data and run epidemiological models. The intern will collaborate with our partners at Snowflake to develop a web application that integrates user-provided surveillance data with mobility datasets to automatically generate epidemic indicators and trend estimates, without requiring modeling expertise. The prototype will be tested and applied to respiratory virus surveillance in Gabon, in collaboration with our local partners

The intern will work in Python-based environments with Snowflake engineers to:

  • Integrate (computationally lightweight) epidemic models and mobility datasets into the backend of the web app.
  • Contribute to the frontend interface design and data visualization.

If you would like to have more information please contact Eugenio Valdano.

To apply for the internship please use this link. The position will be filled as soon a suitable candidate is found.

item.title: Internship - Foundation models for epidemic modeling and public health policy evaluation
item.description:
We are looking for an intern to apply foundation models to modeling epidemics and informing public health strategies (e.g., immunization campaigns, mobility restrictions). Candidates will be 1st-year or 2nd-year master students in computer science, machine learning, physics applied mathematics, engineering or other relevant fields. The starting date can be from late 2025, onwards. Internships typically last 6 months.

If you would like to have more information please contact Eugenio Valdano.

To apply for the internship please use this link. The position will be filled as soon a suitable candidate is found.

item.title: Internship - Low-dimensional representations of realistic, heterogeneous epidemic models
item.description:
We are looking for an intern to join our research on devising and applying complex systems physics and deep learning methods to finding low-dimensional interpretable representations of realistic epidemic processes. Python skills, possibly with previous experience with pytorch, and a strong ability to learn are essential.

Candidates will be 1st-year or 2nd-year master students in computer science, machine learning, physics, applied mathematics, engineering or other relevant fields. The starting date can be from late 2025, onwards. Internships typically last 6 months. The starting date can be from late 2025, onwards. Internships typically last 6 months.

If you would like to have more information please contact Eugenio Valdano.

To apply for the internship please use this link. The position will be filled as soon a suitable candidate is found.

item.title: Internship - Mobility-informed risk mapping
item.description:
We are looking for an intern to join our research on integrating large-scale, high-resolution mobility data to build exposure risk maps for infectious disease epidemics. The data will be provided by Meta - see this for how we used similar data. We will study how time spent in different locations shapes the risk of exposure to infectious diseases, applying to mosquito-borne diseases. Basic Python skills are required. Previous knowledge/experience in data analysis is a plus. Candidates will generally be 1st-year or 2nd-year master students in computer science, machine learning, physics, applied mathematics, engineering or other relevant fields.

See this previous publication for a similar approach.

If you would like to have more information please contact Eugenio Valdano.

To apply for the internship please use this link. The position will be filled as soon a suitable candidate is found.

item.title: New grant funded! DiscoReel
item.description: The French National Research Agency ANR has just selected and will fund our grant DiscoReel, under the funding scheme Jeunes Chercheuses et Jeunes Chercheurs (JCJC). It will last for 3 years and allow us to recruit a computer scientists. Stay tuned for job postings soon!

item.title: Complexity72h 2025 - call for tutors
item.description:
The 2025 edition of Complexity72H will take place at the Carlos III University in Madrid, Spain, from June 23 to June 27 2025.

Complexity72h is an interdisciplinary workshop for young researchers in complex systems. Participants form teams and carry out projects in a three days’ time, i.e. 72 hours. The goal of each team is to complete and upload a report of their work by the end of the event.

Participants will work in teams, and each team will have a tutor. Tutors design the project, bring in the necessary data, and manage the team.

Do you have an idea for a project that can be carried out in our scientific hackaton? Are you motivated to work non-stop for 3 days with a motivated and enthusiastic bunch of students and young researchers? Then we need you! Apply to the call for tutors now!

Are you a young researcher who has just recently become senior, or is in the process of doing so? Then this is the perfect opportunity for you to experiment with your leadership skills. Also, many scientific collaborations were born at Complexity72h and then continued over the years, giving you the opportunity to broaden your collaboration network.

Contact us if you need more info and apply!

Visit our website www.complexity72h.com and follow us on X and LinkedIn.

item.title: Welcome Benjamin!
item.description: Benjamin joins the group as a postdoctoral researcher funded by the European project SIESTA.

item.title: Moving into the new offices
item.description: We are at the 5th floor of the Faculty of Health of Sorbonne University at the St. Antoine hospital. Our newly renovated offices are at the SUMOC center.

item.title: (position filled) Come work with us: open postdoc position @ EV / The modelers
item.description:
This position has been filled. Do visit our website periodically for more openings.

==========================

Come work with EV / The modelers. We are opening a postdoc position at the lab funded by the European project SIESTA.

We are looking for a motivated researcher wishing to work on data-driven modeling of epidemic spread. We seek expertise either in physics of complex systems / complex networks or in statistical inference, expecially with deep-learning.

You will work on developing new-generation mathematical models of epidemic spread coupling them to large-scale datasets at high spatial and temporal resolution, including human behavior.

Use THIS FORM to apply.

Details:

  • application period: flexible, the position will be filled as soon as we find a suitable candidate;
  • start of the contract: flexible, to be discussed with the candidate. Allow at least two months for the administrative process;
  • duration of the contract: 1.5 years, extendable;
  • employer: Inserm;
  • gross monthly salary: ~3,000 euros for a recent PhD graduate, subject to changes to Inserm salary grids.

item.title: EV / The Modelers now on the Italian ILI Forecast platform Influcast
item.description:
Influcast is platform to forecast the evolution of the incidence of influenza-like-illness in Italy by integrating prediction from multiple teams and models. It is coordinated by the ISI Foundation. EV / The Modelers now provides weekly estimates to Influcast.

Through our collaboration with Influcast, our goal is to push the methodological boundaries of mathematical models. Partnering up with our colleagues at the computer science dept. of the University of Bologna, Italy, we are developing a model that combines mechanistic mathematical modeling of epidemic dynamics with deep-learning based inference from data, using physics-informed neural networks.

The interaction with Influcast allows us to assess and improve the performance of our models in a nowcasting scenario and to benchmark them against existing forecasting frameworks.

item.title: The 5th edition of Complexity72H
item.description:
Apply to the 2024 edition of Complexity72H!

It will take place at the Carlos III University in Madrid, Spain, from June 24 to June 28 2024.

Complexity72h is an interdisciplinary workshop for young researchers in complex systems. Participants form teams and carry out projects in a three days’ time, i.e. 72 hours. The goal of each team is to complete and upload a report of their work by the end of the event.

Thanks to the support of our partners we are keeping very low participation fees so that everyone can apply! Also, we will grant partial and full fee waivers to a selected number of applicants.

Visit our website for all the info! You will find

  • our lecturers
  • our tutors and the projects they are proposing
  • the instructions on how to apply

APPLY HERE until Jan 31, 2023.

item.title: Complexity72H is back!
item.description:
Complexity72H is back after COVID.

Complexity72h is an interdisciplinary workshop for young researchers in complex systems. Participants form teams and carry out projects in a three days’ time, i.e. 72 hours. The goal of each team is to upload on the arXiv (or similar repositories) a report of their work by the end of the event. The editions of 2018 and 2019 were a success: 11 out of 11 projects have become arXiv preprints and new collaborations have been born. The 2020 edition was canceled due to the pandemic. But we are now back for a 2023 edition, which will take place in Palma (Mallorca, Spain) on June 26-30.

Check our the call for tutors and the call for applications on our website!
